com.avaya.csta.terminal

Class TerminalAdapter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.avaya.csta.terminal.TerminalAdapter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TerminalListener, java.util.EventListener
    Deprecated. 
    As of release 3.1, replaced by RegistrationAdapter

    public class TerminalAdapter
extends java.lang.Object
implements TerminalListener
    Implements a "do nothing" callback method for each terminal registration event type. To learn more about how to use a listener adapter, see Using Listeners in the Device, Media & Call Control (DMCC) API.
    Version:
    $Revision: 1.3 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.

    • Method Detail

      • registered

        public void registered(RegisteredEvent event)
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from interface: TerminalListener
        Callback method that is called when device successfully completes registration following a TerminalServices.registerDevice() request. See the RegisteredEvent for more information.

        The device parameter that specifies the device that is registered is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();
        Specified by:
        registered in interface TerminalListener
        Parameters:
        event - an indication that registration has completed successfully for the specified device

      • registerFailed

        public void registerFailed(RegisterFailedEvent event)
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from interface: TerminalListener
        Callback method that is called when device fails to complete registration following a TerminalServices.registerDevice() request. See the RegisterFailedEvent for more information. TerminalServices will not try registering again unless a new request to registerDevice is made. The reason for the failure is contained in the RegisterFailedEvent. The application is expected to resolve the problem (e.g., bad password, invalid extension, no connectivity to the switch, etc.) before trying again.

        The device parameter that specifies the device that is registered is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();

        An example of how getReason() and getCode() might be used is shown below: 

         // Check to see if registration failed because of network timeout
 if (event.getCode().equals RegistrationConstants.NETWORK_TIMEOUT) {
     System.out.println("registerFailed: Code: " + event.getCode()
         + " Reason: " + event.getReason());
     System.out.println("Will try to register again after waiting 30 secs.");
     Thread.sleep(30000);
     // Try registering again in case network problems were temporary.
     ...
     }
        Specified by:
        registerFailed in interface TerminalListener
        Parameters:
        event - an indication that registration has failed. Use event.getReason() or event.getCode() to determine the cause of the failure.

      • unregistered

        public void unregistered(UnregisterEvent event)
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from interface: TerminalListener
        Callback method that is called when device is unregistered from the switching function. This event occurs after the unregisterDevice method is called from TerminalServices. It can also occur when the switching function unregisters the device (for whatever reason). In either case, a reason for the unregistration will be present in the event. See the UnregisterEvent for more information.

        The device parameter that specifies the device that is registered is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();

        An example of how getReason() and getCode() might be used is shown below: 

         // Check to see if device was automically unregistered because of network
 // timeout
 if (event.getCode().equals RegistrationConstants.NETWORK_TIMEOUT) {
     System.out.println("unregistered: Code: " + event.getCode()
         + " Reason: " + event.getReason());
     System.out.println("Will try to re-register after waiting 30 secs.");
     Thread.sleep(30000);
     // Try to re-register in case network problems were temporary.
     ...
     }
        Specified by:
        unregistered in interface TerminalListener
        Parameters:
        event - indication that the device is now unregistered. Use event.getReason() or event.getCode()to determine the cause of the unregistration.
